content.description:
This is the preferred access to the upper wall.  It has fixed anchors for the decent set at a long 70 meter single rope rappels.

P1: Climb up the line of weakness using a mixture of chimney and face to a set of fixed anchors out on the right wall, 5.7, 100' +/-.

P2: Continue up the gash culminating at a cleaner, steep, wide section at the top to a two bolt belay, 5.9+, 120' +/-.

Climb 5th Class to the big ledge.
content.protection: A standard alpine rack with extra larger units up to a #5 Camalot.
content.location: This climb starts at the apex where the steep treed slope meets the lower wall.

content.description:
It is hard to believe this kind of rig is still out there unclimbed, but they’re around here. This was a four day adventure for us - big days figuring out the hike in and climbing the lower slabs. We went ground up, equipping and cleaning as we went. We led it with a mix of free and aid, but the follower was able to follow free on most of it. The last two pitches are the crux. We were not able to continuously follow those. On pitch 4, we got with a couple of hangs, and it probably clocks in around 11+OW after a solid 11 sequence. Pitch 5 tackles the steepest part the huge roof that caps the entire route. We got that clean on follow, but the headwall above needed some work and is a bit dirty. Led at C2, we didn’t put any bolts in, because we wanted to leave it clean for the next generation. This pitch is probably solid 12, and what a fantastic grand finale - busting moves like that over 1000’ of air -f#@king Bannanas Man!

You need to figure out the lower slab “Kung Flue 5.9” is the quickest option. 250’ later you're on the big ledge and hiking unroped up to the base of the huge corner that marks our line of ascent.

P1. This is a great pitch clocking at solid 10+ mostly hands and smaller. Climb above the belay, and downclimb for the true send or clip the fixed nut and tension over to two bolts and a nice stance!, 5.10 110’+/-.

P2. Step up your game to ascend these double stacked roofs. Climb the first one with micros and a few finger-sized pieces, then climb through the chimney up to a second wide roof. We put a bolt in at the lip of the second roof to help take some of the sting out. This last section was led on #7 & #8 BDs, 5.11, 110’ +/- .

P3. Climb another sweet pitch through a runout slab passing a corner to an arete to an hand and finger crack with sweeping exposure- a sweet pitch! A bolt was added to this slab after the fact.  We both agreed there was significant fall potential on sketchy gear and decided to protect the hardest moves.  5.9, 90’ +/-.

P4. You're getting up there now. Climb this difficult chimney with a finger crack for protection. Pass the roof to a solid 5.11 OW that was led on  #8/#7/#6 BDs - easy pulling if you have the right gear. This pitch deposits you on a great ledge right below the huge roof, 5.9 C1 (5.11 TR), 110’ +/-.

P5. The “

cou de grace

” ascent the finger crack up and out the 10’ horizontal roof - pull the lip to more hard free climbing and some less stellar rock. To make an honest free attempt of this, you would want to clean up the headwall; pretty good moves - lots of lichen. We got the roof at V4/5 but lost it on the headwall. Summit to natural anchors. There are fixed anchors for the descent are 15’ skier's left of the line of ascent and make for a fairly plumb rap to the last belay, which is also very hard to get back to because of steepness if you don’t plan ahead, 5.9 C2, 100’+/-.

We tried equipped this rig for single rope rappelling.  A lot of the stations are hard to get back to without some issues due to its leaning nature. From the fourth pitch, you can drop directly down onto “Masks Required”, which is another free route in progress, and rappel direct down its line of ascent on those stations with two ropes.

Approach pitches: 1st short rap off skinny tree, then double rope rap through to

Kung Flue

1st pitch belay.  Then single rope to the ground.
content.protection: Triples from thin fingers to wide hands, double micros, singles up to the new #8 BD, two ropes, and lots of runners.
content.location: This climb ascends the obvious, left-leaning corner system that runs the entire length of the right side of the upper wall.

content.description:
Biden Your Time is a wandering, 4 pitch line that was sort of a thrash. Pick the line of least resistance below the obvious corner on the upper wall. Several short cruxes up to 5.11 on less than stellar rock get you to the big ledge.

P1. From the deep chimney, work your way left encountering a wide crux 5.10+, and wander up to belay from natural anchors on a ledge with trees, 70' +/-.

P2. Climb straight up to the base of a wild rib, then climb the rib, turning the corner at the top belay from natural anchors, 120' +/-.

P3. Piece together the face climb on some heinous lichen, 5.11, 100' +/-.

P4. Fifth class a wandering line through the bushes to the big ledge, 100' +/- .
content.protection: Two ropes and a standard alpine rack with lots of long runners.
content.location: Look for the big cleft at the farthest right of the lower wall. Wander up the line of least resistance from here.
